title: How to Raise a Vegetarian Baby: First Foods

methods.name: Consulting a Qualified Health Care Provider Who Supports Your Decision

steps.headline: Ask your current pediatrician if they support the idea of a vegetarian diet.
steps.description: If they do not, you may want to look elsewhere for the knowledge and support that you may need to guide you.

steps.headline: Speak to your pediatrician to determine if your baby is a good candidate for a vegetarian diet.
steps.description: It may not be wise to start your baby on a vegetarian diet if there are other health concerns present. Get a clean bill of health for your baby before moving forward. It is a good idea to have them checked for nutritional deficiencies. A simple blood test will be able to determine if they are lacking in any nutrients such as iron. If deficiencies are detected, speak with your pediatrician about treatment options. Depending on the specific deficiency, it may be possible to continue with your plans for a vegetarian diet.

steps.headline: Locate a nutritionist or a registered dietitian who is knowledgeable in vegetarian diets.
steps.description: Babies can be very picky, especially when first starting out on solid foods. While bananas are an excellent source of potassium, your baby may simply refuse to eat them. This is where working with a nutritionist can be helpful, as they can recommend other foods that have a high potassium content.

steps.headline: Introduce only one food at a time.
steps.description: Continue with the same one food for 3 to 5 days to allow time for any allergic reactions to surface. If you observe any signs of a possible allergic reaction, discontinue that food and consult your pediatrician. Symptoms of a food allergy in babies include a red rash on the body, red or swollen lips or cheeks, swelling of the tongue, itching, coughing and difficulty breathing. If you notice that your baby is making strange sounds or if they appear to be choking, seek immediate medical treatment.

steps.headline: Offer rice or oat single grain cereal before offering fruit and vegetable varieties.
steps.description: Choose cereals that are fortified with iron. If your baby is formula-fed, use an iron-fortified formula to prepare the cereal. These 2 steps will ensure that your baby is getting all of the iron that they need, an essential mineral that is sometimes lacking in vegetarian diets.

steps.headline: Introduce vegetables and fruits one at a time.
steps.description: Start with vegetables first and then move onto fruits. Stick with one type of vegetable or fruit for 3 to 5 days before moving onto another variety. This will give you enough time to determine if your baby has an allergy to a particular food. By isolating one food for a few days, you will be able to pinpoint the exact culprit if allergic symptoms do develop. Cook all vegetables thoroughly and be sure to mash it well to prevent choking. To make a thinner consistency, use a food processor to puree the food. Green beans, carrots, peas, and potatoes are all good first vegetarian foods. Be sure to mash fruits well before giving them to your baby. Good choices for first fruits for vegetarian babies include mashed bananas, strained peaches, applesauce, and mashed avocados.

steps.headline: Offer daily sources of protein from eggs, beans, dairy, rice, tofu, wheat cereals, and bread.
steps.description: When your baby can handle it, introduce nuts and seeds. Most pediatricians recommend waiting to introduce nuts until the baby is 18 months old to reduce the risk of nut allergies. Speak with your pediatrician to determine when would be a good time to start your baby on them.

steps.headline: Check the labels of baby foods for their iron count.
steps.description: Introduce plenty of iron-rich sources of chickpeas, dark green vegetables, bread, and iron-fortified cereals, into the diet. Add vitamin C sources to help the body absorb iron better.

steps.headline: Include milk, eggs, dairy products, yeast extract and cereal fortified with B12 as good sources of vitamin B12.
steps.description: Remember that breast milk and formula are excellent sources of vitamin B12 for the first year of baby's life.

steps.headline: Add foods rich in selenium to your baby's diet.
steps.description: Selenium can be found in nuts, bagels, sunflower seeds, egg noodles, and rice. Once given clearance by your pediatrician to start your baby on nuts, offer them some nut butters to avoid the risk of choking on whole nuts.

steps.headline: Provide plenty of sources of calcium.
steps.description: Check labels for calcium enrichment. Many foods on the market today are fortified with calcium. Give your baby whole milk yogurt and cheeses.

steps.headline: Ensure high-calorie intake by offering your baby frequent feedings of high-calorie foods.
steps.description: Because they will not be eating meats, they are likely to be hungrier more often than if they were not a vegetarian. Be sure to offer plenty of snacks and meals throughout the day.

steps.headline: Avoid offering a lot of fiber-rich foods.
Plan meals wisely.
steps.description: Offer as much of the needed nutrients and calories as possible. Balance out the meal. Do not over-compensate with too much of one nutrient and not enough of another. A vegetarian diet, like any, requires a good balance of healthy nutrients.

steps.headline: Combine foods.
steps.description: Using a combination of different foods at one time is an easy way to incorporate more of the beneficial nutrients that you are trying to provide for your baby. Try serving multiple sources of nutritional foods such as rice with beans, bread with cheese and hummus with pita bread. Don't be afraid to think outside the box. Vegetarian diets have to be creative and it's never too early to start your baby on a wide variety of foods.

text: Consulting a Qualified Health Care Provider Who Supports Your Decision Ask your current pediatrician if they support the idea of a vegetarian diet. If they do not, you may want to look elsewhere for the knowledge and support that you may need to guide you. Speak to your pediatrician to determine if your baby is a good candidate for a vegetarian diet. It may not be wise to start your baby on a vegetarian diet if there are other health concerns present. Get a clean bill of health for your baby before moving forward. It is a good idea to have them checked for nutritional deficiencies. A simple blood test will be able to determine if they are lacking in any nutrients such as iron. If deficiencies are detected, speak with your pediatrician about treatment options. Depending on the specific deficiency, it may be possible to continue with your plans for a vegetarian diet. Locate a nutritionist or a registered dietitian who is knowledgeable in vegetarian diets. Babies can be very picky, especially when first starting out on solid foods. While bananas are an excellent source of potassium, your baby may simply refuse to eat them. This is where working with a nutritionist can be helpful, as they can recommend other foods that have a high potassium content. Introducing Solids Introduce only one food at a time. Continue with the same one food for 3 to 5 days to allow time for any allergic reactions to surface. If you observe any signs of a possible allergic reaction, discontinue that food and consult your pediatrician. Symptoms of a food allergy in babies include a red rash on the body, red or swollen lips or cheeks, swelling of the tongue, itching, coughing and difficulty breathing. If you notice that your baby is making strange sounds or if they appear to be choking, seek immediate medical treatment. Offer rice or oat single grain cereal before offering fruit and vegetable varieties. Choose cereals that are fortified with iron. If your baby is formula-fed, use an iron-fortified formula to prepare the cereal. These 2 steps will ensure that your baby is getting all of the iron that they need, an essential mineral that is sometimes lacking in vegetarian diets. Introduce vegetables and fruits one at a time. Start with vegetables first and then move onto fruits. Stick with one type of vegetable or fruit for 3 to 5 days before moving onto another variety. This will give you enough time to determine if your baby has an allergy to a particular food. By isolating one food for a few days, you will be able to pinpoint the exact culprit if allergic symptoms do develop. Cook all vegetables thoroughly and be sure to mash it well to prevent choking. To make a thinner consistency, use a food processor to puree the food. Green beans, carrots, peas, and potatoes are all good first vegetarian foods. Be sure to mash fruits well before giving them to your baby. Good choices for first fruits for vegetarian babies include mashed bananas, strained peaches, applesauce, and mashed avocados. Feeding Baby Only Nutritious Foods Offer daily sources of protein from eggs, beans, dairy, rice, tofu, wheat cereals, and bread. When your baby can handle it, introduce nuts and seeds. Most pediatricians recommend waiting to introduce nuts until the baby is 18 months old to reduce the risk of nut allergies. Speak with your pediatrician to determine when would be a good time to start your baby on them. Check the labels of baby foods for their iron count. Introduce plenty of iron-rich sources of chickpeas, dark green vegetables, bread, and iron-fortified cereals, into the diet. Add vitamin C sources to help the body absorb iron better. Include milk, eggs, dairy products, yeast extract and cereal fortified with B12 as good sources of vitamin B12. Remember that breast milk and formula are excellent sources of vitamin B12 for the first year of baby's life. Add foods rich in selenium to your baby's diet. Selenium can be found in nuts, bagels, sunflower seeds, egg noodles, and rice. Once given clearance by your pediatrician to start your baby on nuts, offer them some nut butters to avoid the risk of choking on whole nuts. Provide plenty of sources of calcium. Check labels for calcium enrichment. Many foods on the market today are fortified with calcium. Give your baby whole milk yogurt and cheeses. Ensure high-calorie intake by offering your baby frequent feedings of high-calorie foods. Because they will not be eating meats, they are likely to be hungrier more often than if they were not a vegetarian. Be sure to offer plenty of snacks and meals throughout the day. Avoid offering a lot of fiber-rich foods. Small tummies fill up quickly. Plan meals wisely. Offer as much of the needed nutrients and calories as possible. Balance out the meal. Do not over-compensate with too much of one nutrient and not enough of another. A vegetarian diet, like any, requires a good balance of healthy nutrients. Combine foods. Using a combination of different foods at one time is an easy way to incorporate more of the beneficial nutrients that you are trying to provide for your baby. Try serving multiple sources of nutritional foods such as rice with beans, bread with cheese and hummus with pita bread. Don't be afraid to think outside the box. Vegetarian diets have to be creative and it's never too early to start your baby on a wide variety of foods.
